bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to [s.n.] Williamson, January 6, 1924

div1.p: Carter writes that he is returning Williamson's manuscript with comments.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to [s.n.] Williamson, January 6, 1924
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Fish
(in remosquito
control)
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
January 6, 1924.
Dear Doctor Williamson:
div1.p:
I am returning (under separate cover) the galley proof of the
article on “The use of Fish for the Control of Mosquitoes” with
notes thereon on separate sheets. These notes are marked with the
number of the page of proof and the marginal numeral of the place
on that page to which such note refers.

Most of them are of no great importance and are simply intended
to present little bits of information which possibly was not in the
mind of the writer when this part of the article was written. Rare-
ly would they render a change in the MSS advisable.

This had been done long ago, but I had to make depositions (from
my bed) in three law suits during December, which took up much time
(10 or 12 days) and left me somewhat less well than I had been.
These are off my hands now and I am entirely willing, and I think
able, to pass on any papers or questions which you may think it ad-
visable to submit to me. Indeed, it is no small satisfaction to me
if I can still be of service in sanitary work--especially that against
yellow fever.
